content.body: A question about `import defer`. Currently, a module include top level-await will not be deferred. Could we allow implementations do some static analysis and optimization to defer the sync part (code after the last `await` expression) ?
content.formatted_body: A question about import defer. Currently, a module include top level-await will not be deferred. Could we allow implementations do some static analysis and optimization to defer the sync part (code after the last await expression) ?

content.body: Wouldn't that break run until completion semantics?
Maybe not if it, as you say,  doesn't start to run
content.formatted_body: Maybe not if it, as you say,  doesn't start to run

content.body: I'm not sure how big a saving g that would add, just the last part of one module
content.formatted_body: I'm not sure how big a saving g that would add, just the last part of one module

content.body: * I'm not sure how big a saving that would add, just the last part of one module

m.new_content.body: I'm not sure how big a saving that would add, just the last part of one module

content.body: Interesting idea though, I'd love to try it out on our version of `import defer` at Bloomberg but our equivalent of TLA isn't as statically analysable so not really possible
